description: A rich, slow-baked casserole of tender beans cooked in a clay pot with ghee until creamy and deeply flavorful, creating a comforting one-pot dish.

cultural_significance.cultural_notes: Firinda refers to the traditional method of slow-baking in a clay pot over embers or in a modern oven. This method allows the beans to become exceptionally creamy and absorb all the rich flavors of the ghee and aromatics.

ingredients.name: Dry Beans
ingredients.notes: Red kidney beans or any local variety, soaked overnight

steps.instruction: Drain the beans that were soaked overnight and rinse them thoroughly under cold running water.
If using a traditional clay pot (firinda), soak it in water for 15-20 minutes to prevent cracking during cooking.
Melt 2 tablespoons of ghee in the clay pot or heavy oven-safe pot over medium heat. Add chopped onions and sauté until golden brown, about 8-10 minutes.
Add minced garlic and grated ginger. Sauté for 2 minutes until fragrant.
Add turmeric and cumin powder. Stir for 30 seconds to toast the spices.
Add the grated tomatoes and cook for 5-7 minutes until the mixture thickens and the oil starts to separate from the sides.
Add the drained beans to the pot and stir well to coat with the tomato-spice mixture.
Pour in water and add salt. Bring to a gentle boil, then reduce heat to low.
Cover the pot and let it simmer slowly for 2-3 hours. If using an oven, bake at 160°C (320°F) for the same duration. Stir occasionally and add more hot water if needed.

cooking_indicators.visual: beans become very tender and creamy, sauce thickens
cooking_indicators.texture: beans should mash easily between fingers

steps.instruction: About 30 minutes before the end of cooking, stir in the remaining 2 tablespoons of ghee and diced green pepper (if using). This will enrich the flavor and aroma.
When the beans are completely tender and the sauce is thick and creamy, remove from heat. The beans should have a rich, buttery flavor from the ghee.
Let it rest for 10 minutes before serving. The firinda will continue to thicken as it cools slightly.
Serve hot with Ugali, Chapati, or Rice, drizzled with extra ghee if desired.

serving_suggestions: Best served hot with Ugali, Chapati, or Rice. Can be accompanied by fresh avocado or kachumbari (fresh tomato and onion salad).
